messageBody:
amd64_hacker wrote:
> I can't think of a single case where Variant Selectors would actually
> be useful, and that's probably the best argument there is for
> removing it.
> I do think the the flexibility is unnecessary in the Unicode proposal.
> The more advanced typography packages allow you to override the glyphs
> choices at the API level already.
> And I'm not sure that the flexibility is needed for raw text, html,
> word documents and so on.
>
> If you disagree and you can think of an argument that we can put to
> the UTC let me know and I'll add it to the proposal.
> Otherwise I think we should drop it.

I think I've found an argument.

IIUC You wrote "A caseless, phonetic, left-to-right alphabet optimised for
the
English language ( b u t s t i l l u s e f u l f o r o t h e r
l a n g u a g e s with
similar sounds) created by (Ronald) Kingsley Read."

I've found an adaptation of QS to Dutch on Wikipedia:
http://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quickscript. Different sounds have been
assigned to some QS letters (particularly Dutch diphtongs have been assigned
to two consonant letters!).

Several times I've tried myself to adapt QS to my native tongue: French.
In French there are four nasal consonants: /m/, /n/, /ɲ/ (similar to the
Spanish |ñ|, n with tilde, but commonly spelled |gn|) and /ŋ/ which is
retained in a few words of English origin, especially those ending in
"-ing". There are also nasal vowels (three or four following the dialects),
which are clearly distinguished from oral vowel + |n|.

In some of my attempts I've used the normal form of n for /n/ and its
variant form for |ɲ| (i.e. |ñ|, |gn|).
In such cases, I think it would be useful to have control over the form of
some letters.

For the same reason, I also think it would be best to consider QS as an
extension of the Shavian alphabet and encode the alternate forms and the
half letters separately, just like the Latin capital and small letters are
encoded separately, although most software will find "WORD" if you're
looking for "word". That would allow the persons who need new letters to use
Shavian letters as additional QS letters in their adaptations to other
languages, and this would allow to keep QS more phonemic accross different
languages.

Jean-François Colson


PS I think Opentype fonts don't work properly on Linux computers. I've read
somewhere that Graphite support would be added to Open Office but presently
that's only a project.

And if you keep the idea of using variation selectors to display variant
forms or half letters, I'm afraid we'll have to wait a few additional years
(perhaps a decade) until an updated version of Uniscribe will perhaps
support those alternate forms in a future version of Windows.
In one word, keep it simple. I think the system ONE CODE POINT = ONE GLYPH,
ONE GLYPH = ONE CODE POINT will be the easiest one to implement and it would
be immediately supported by most operating systems.
